Former Northeastern deputy AD was walking to Whole Foods. Then the police officers surrounded him. One drew his gun“There’s a party meeting the description of the party we are looking for,” the officer radioed when he saw Tim Duncan. Seconds later, the officer announced, “We have him surrounded.”

One man lays wreaths in Normandy on this unusual D-Day anniversaryThe essence of war remembrance is to make sure the fallen are never forgotten. This year, though, the pandemic stepped in, barring all travel for families to visit the World War II graves in France's Normandy, where Saturday marks the 76th anniversary of the epic D-Day battle.

The sight of troops in Boston’s toniest neighborhood in recent days has been jarringOn Boylston Street on Thursday, a handful of soldiers stood in their fatigues. A block away, in front of an upscale women’s boutique, a soldier sat on the hood of a massive military vehicle. And on Newbury Street another cluster of armed troops kept watch near Tiffany’s and the boarded-up Burberry store.

Protest for Black Lives Matter in Providence is massive -- and peacefulA massive and peaceful protest of 10,000 marchers that filled downtown streets and the State House steps grew tense as the city’s 9 p.m. curfew arrived and a couple of hundred demonstrators refused to go home. But police decided not to enforce the curfew, and the event ended quietly.

For mothers of Black sons, George Floyd’s death  is their worst fear made real — againBetween Trayvon Martin and George Floyd, Monalisa Smith’s son has gone to college, launched a career in finance, and bought a home. In that time, untold numbers of Black Americans have died at the hands of police officers and others, to whom their lives are worthless. Does she hold out any hope it could be different?

A block away, in front of an upscale women’s boutique, a soldier sat on the hood of a massive military vehicle. And on Newbury Street another cluster of armed troops kept watch near Tiffany’s and the boarded-up Burberry store.

Amid national unrest, President Trump visits small Maine town to tout his successPresident Trump’s trip to rural Maine marked his first time away from the capital since massive protests broke out across the nation over the death of George Floyd.

For mothers of Black sons, George Floyd’s death  is their worst fear made real — againBetween Trayvon Martin and George Floyd, Monalisa Smith’s son has gone to college, launched a career in finance, and bought a home. In that time, untold numbers of Black Americans have died at the hands of police officers and others, to whom their lives are worthless. Does she hold out any hope it could be different?

But police decided not to enforce the curfew, and the event ended quietly.

For mothers of Black sons, George Floyd’s death  is their worst fear made real — againBetween Trayvon Martin and George Floyd, Monalisa Smith’s son has gone to college, launched a career in finance, and bought a home. In that time, untold numbers of Black Americans have died at the hands of police officers and others, to whom their lives are worthless. Does she hold out any hope it could be different?

The sight of troops in Boston’s toniest neighborhood in recent days has been jarringOn Boylston Street on Thursday, a handful of soldiers stood in their fatigues. A block away, in front of an upscale women’s boutique, a soldier sat on the hood of a massive military vehicle. And on Newbury Street another cluster of armed troops kept watch near Tiffany’s and the boarded-up Burberry store.

Yvonne AbrahamFor mothers of Black sons, George Floyd’s death  is their worst fear made real — againBetween Trayvon Martin and George Floyd, Monalisa Smith’s son has gone to college, launched a career in finance, and bought a home. In that time, untold numbers of Black Americans have died at the hands of police officers and others, to whom their lives are worthless. Does she hold out any hope it could be different?

Judge rules Interior Department decision on Mashpee Wampanoag violates lawA US District Court judge has ordered the federal Department of the Interior to reconsider its 2018 decision that threatened the status of the Mashpee Wampanoag, writing that the agency didn’t follow its own legal guidance in making that determination.

The sight of troops in Boston’s toniest neighborhood in recent days has been jarringOn Boylston Street on Thursday, a handful of soldiers stood in their fatigues. A block away, in front of an upscale women’s boutique, a soldier sat on the hood of a massive military vehicle. And on Newbury Street another cluster of armed troops kept watch near Tiffany’s and the boarded-up Burberry store.

Yvonne AbrahamFor mothers of Black sons, George Floyd’s death  is their worst fear made real — againBetween Trayvon Martin and George Floyd, Monalisa Smith’s son has gone to college, launched a career in finance, and bought a home. In that time, untold numbers of Black Americans have died at the hands of police officers and others, to whom their lives are worthless. Does she hold out any hope it could be different?

The sight of troops in Boston’s toniest neighborhood in recent days has been jarringOn Boylston Street on Thursday, a handful of soldiers stood in their fatigues. A block away, in front of an upscale women’s boutique, a soldier sat on the hood of a massive military vehicle. And on Newbury Street another cluster of armed troops kept watch near Tiffany’s and the boarded-up Burberry store.

Judge rules Interior Department decision on Mashpee Wampanoag violates lawA US District Court judge has ordered the federal Department of the Interior to reconsider its 2018 decision that threatened the status of the Mashpee Wampanoag, writing that the agency didn’t follow its own legal guidance in making that determination.

YVONNE ABRAHAMFor mothers of Black sons, George Floyd’s death  is their worst fear made real — againBetween Trayvon Martin and George Floyd, Monalisa Smith’s son has gone to college, launched a career in finance, and bought a home. In that time, untold numbers of Black Americans have died at the hands of police officers and others, to whom their lives are worthless. Does she hold out any hope it could be different?

The sight of troops in Boston’s toniest neighborhood in recent days has been jarringOn Boylston Street on Thursday, a handful of soldiers stood in their fatigues. A block away, in front of an upscale women’s boutique, a soldier sat on the hood of a massive military vehicle. And on Newbury Street another cluster of armed troops kept watch near Tiffany’s and the boarded-up Burberry store.

Judge rules Interior Department decision on Mashpee Wampanoag violates lawA US District Court judge has ordered the federal Department of the Interior to reconsider its 2018 decision that threatened the status of the Mashpee Wampanoag, writing that the agency didn’t follow its own legal guidance in making that determination.

YVONNE ABRAHAMFor mothers of Black sons, George Floyd’s death  is their worst fear made real — againBetween Trayvon Martin and George Floyd, Monalisa Smith’s son has gone to college, launched a career in finance, and bought a home. In that time, untold numbers of Black Americans have died at the hands of police officers and others, to whom their lives are worthless. Does she hold out any hope it could be different?

The sight of troops in Boston’s toniest neighborhood in recent days has been jarringOn Boylston Street on Thursday, a handful of soldiers stood in their fatigues. A block away, in front of an upscale women’s boutique, a soldier sat on the hood of a massive military vehicle. And on Newbury Street another cluster of armed troops kept watch near Tiffany’s and the boarded-up Burberry store.

Judge rules Interior Department decision on Mashpee Wampanoag violates lawA US District Court judge has ordered the federal Department of the Interior to reconsider its 2018 decision that threatened the status of the Mashpee Wampanoag, writing that the agency didn’t follow its own legal guidance in making that determination.

YVONNE ABRAHAMFor mothers of Black sons, George Floyd’s death  is their worst fear made real — againBetween Trayvon Martin and George Floyd, Monalisa Smith’s son has gone to college, launched a career in finance, and bought a home. In that time, untold numbers of Black Americans have died at the hands of police officers and others, to whom their lives are worthless. Does she hold out any hope it could be different?

The sight of troops in Boston’s toniest neighborhood in recent days has been jarringOn Boylston Street on Thursday, a handful of soldiers stood in their fatigues. A block away, in front of an upscale women’s boutique, a soldier sat on the hood of a massive military vehicle. And on Newbury Street another cluster of armed troops kept watch near Tiffany’s and the boarded-up Burberry store.

The sight of troops in Boston’s toniest neighborhood in recent days has been jarringOn Boylston Street on Thursday, a handful of soldiers stood in their fatigues. A block away, in front of an upscale women’s boutique, a soldier sat on the hood of a massive military vehicle. And on Newbury Street another cluster of armed troops kept watch near Tiffany’s and the boarded-up Burberry store.

YVONNE ABRAHAMFor mothers of Black sons, George Floyd’s death  is their worst fear made real — againBetween Trayvon Martin and George Floyd, Monalisa Smith’s son has gone to college, launched a career in finance, and bought a home. Boston Board Up has been meeting the demands of businesses trying to protect storefrontsCo-owner Lou Falzarano has been boarding up the storefronts of businesses all over Greater Boston after riots and looting broke out in the city and across the country following peaceful protests against the death of George Floyd.

YVONNE ABRAHAMFor mothers of Black sons, George Floyd’s death  is their worst fear made real — againBetween Trayvon Martin and George Floyd, Monalisa Smith’s son has gone to college, launched a career in finance, and bought a home. In that time, untold numbers of Black Americans have died at the hands of police officers and others, to whom their lives are worthless. Does she hold out any hope it could be different?

The sight of troops in Boston’s toniest neighborhood in recent days has been jarringOn Boylston Street on Thursday, a handful of soldiers stood in their fatigues. A block away, in front of an upscale women’s boutique, a soldier sat on the hood of a massive military vehicle. And on Newbury Street another cluster of armed troops kept watch near Tiffany’s and the boarded-up Burberry store.
